MobileDesc:
"His colossal keyboard mastery is beyond doubt."—The Guardian

The Renaissance man Stephen Hough is one of the reigning stars of classical music—virtuoso pianist and renowned composer as well as painter, writer and poet. In 2001 he became the first classical musician to be named a Macarthur “Genius” Fellow. The honor joins multiple Grammy Award nominations, eight Gramophone Awards, including two for “Record of the Year,” and featured iPad app artist status.

On this program, Mr. Hough gives the New York premiere of his Sonata III (Trinitas), (Read his note on the piece on the “Program Notes” tab above.) His recital also includes Romantic masterpieces by Schubert, Franck and Liszt.

Stephen Hough, piano

MobileDesc:
“A true poet of the keyboard, refined, searching [and] unfailingly communicative.”—London Evening Standard

It’s fair to say that Inon Barnatan has “arrived.” He is a recipient of Lincoln Center’s Martin E. Segal Award for rising artists and is the first artist-in-association of the New York Philharmonic. He has received international praise for his Schubert interpretations and has released four solo CDs since 2010, including two all-Schubert discs. For his second 92Y solo recital, Mr. Barnatan includes Schubert in a wide range of masterworks that reveal different aspects of his artistry.

MobileDesc:
“If you want the sheer joy of human creation and recreation, then go to a piano recital by Angela Hewitt."—The London Times

British/Canadian pianist Angela Hewitt has recorded and performed nearly all of Bach’s works for keyboard—and has secured her reputation as one of the pre-eminent Bach interpreters of our time. But she saved his notoriously challenging final masterwork, The Art of Fugue, for last. Don’t miss the opportunity to hear her interpretation—a performance that has earned her rapturous acclaim from all over the world. As The London Times added, "from the moment she steps sprightly on stage ... you know that the hum of happiness is going to be there.”

Angela Hewitt, piano

BACH: The Art of the Fugue, BWV 1080

This concert is approximately one hour forty minutes long.
ShortDesc: “If you want the sheer joy of human creation and recreation, then go to a piano recital by Angela Hewitt."—The London Times
Title: Angela Hewitt: The Art of the Fugue

MobileDesc:
“Brilliant, perceptive and stunningly fresh. …”—The New York Times

Born in Russia to Jewish parents, Kirill Gerstein came to America to study jazz—but then switched to classical. The recipient of the 2010 Gilmore Award, his 2014 Imaginary Pictures CD was named a “Top CD of the Year” by The New York Times. In other words, he’s rather exceptional.

Gerstein’s program is a dialogue within a dialogue. He opens with an exploration of two seemingly disparate art forms—the structured sonata and free-wheeling fantasia. It expands into a conversation between Western music and the Russia of his roots. But it’s not a quiet debate—the music is fiendishly difficult, which is just as Gerstein wants it.

Kirill Gerstein, piano

BEETHOVEN: Sonata No. 13 in E flat, Op. 27, No. 1, “Quasi una fantasia”

Her program showcases her wizardry at the keyboard, from sparking Scarlatti to one of her signature pieces, which she performed at her Van Cliburn-winning recital—Liszt’s operatic fantasy, a virtuosic showpiece inspired by Mozart’s Don Giovanni.

MobileDesc:
“Jackiw’s ... playing is striking for its intelligence and sensitivity.”—Boston Globe

“Mr. Denk ... [aims] not for simple control or technical wizardry but for the most direct and personal expression.”—The New York Times

“[New York Polyphony has a] rich, natural sound that’s larger and more complex than the sum of its parts.”—NPR

Stefan Jackiw, one of America’s most exciting young violinists, and Jeremy Denk, a 2013 MacArthur “genius” Fellow, offer their artistic insights into an American maverick of classical music—Charles Ives. They will give a rare performance of the complete cycle of Ives’s four violin sonatas in one evening—but that’s not all!

These pieces, like most of Ives’s music, are shot through with quotations from traditional American hymns and songs remembered from the composer’s childhood. In a thoroughly unique approach, New York Polyphony will perform some of those songs, interspersed among the sonatas. It’s a singular opportunity to hear the music of a great American composer who challenged the status quo, and the songs and hymns that inspired him—virtually simultaneously.

Stefan Jackiw, violin
Jeremy Denk, piano
New York Polyphony, vocal ensemble

IVES: Violin Sonatas Nos. 1-4 (complete)
Interspersed with traditional American hymns and songs

This concert is approximately one hour fifty minutes long.
ShortDesc: “Jackiw’s ... playing is striking for its intelligence and sensitivity.”—Boston Globe
Title: Stefan Jackiw, violin, Jeremy Denk, piano & New York Polyphony, vocal ensemble

“Mr. Wosner’s singing tone and expressive musicality complemented Ms. Koh’s insightful, richly hued playing.”—The New York Times

Jennifer Koh and Shai Wosner have each created intriguing programs that draw lines between the canons of the classical music repertoire and exciting new works from our time. Now they “double up” to present a series of concerts on the true Olympian—Ludwig van Beethoven—and his impact and significance on composers of today.

In each program Koh and Wosner will perform select Beethoven violin sonatas interspersed with a new work composed in response to those specific sonatas. For this program, the composer is the award-winning young Californian, Andrew Norman, Join us for this unique cross-culture, cross-centuries conversation.

Jennifer Koh, violin
Shai Wosner, piano

“Bridge to Beethoven”

ANDREW NORMAN: New work (NYC premiere)

MobileDesc:
“An inspired duo, perfectly balanced musically.”—The Guardian

Individually, cellist Steven Isserlis and pianist/composer Stephen Hough are sublime. Together they make one of classical music’s foremost duos. They bring a program that is centered on Romantic masterpieces for cello and piano, from Bohemia’s Dvo≈ô√°k to Norway’s Grieg.

They also bring some wistful Schubert that was originally written for an “arpeggione,” a melding of cello and guitar that was a fad in the 1820s. (Steven will play it on his 1727 Stradivarius.) Plus, Stephen will demonstrate his composing skills with a Cello Sonata he wrote specifically for his friend. It’s a thrill to share such a personal experience: an artist performing a work that was written for him—with the composer playing along!

Steven Isserlis, cello
Stephen Hough, piano

Avi Avital is on a crusade: To transform the sweet, folkoric mandolin into a thoroughly modern instrument, capable of astonishing virtuosity and profound poignancy. The first mandolin player to receive a Grammy Award nomination, Avital and his trio take a genre-defying tour of the globe, blurring borders between folk, classical and popular music. The program ranges from the Baroque Bach to traditional Turkish tunes. A perfect program for anyone who literally loves “the world of music.”

This young Brazilian virtuoso, who has been blazing through the guitar world, returns to 92Y with his Brazilian seven-stringed guitar. (The extra string usually gives added depth to the bass). Costa is a champion of the choro, a form of Brazilian music marked by fast and happy rhythm, virtuosity, improvisation and modulations. In a program that includes his own works, he brings us a magical night of exuberant music from South America.

MobileDesc:
Porat’s accompaniment of The General was “an astounding feat of creative musicianship.”—The New Yorker

Israeli composer-pianist Matan Porat puts both talents on full display when he creates a live and totally improvised score to accompany Buster Keaton’s cinematic masterpiece, The General. It’s a chance to relive the 1920s when all silent films were accompanied by live music—either a full orchestra or a single piano. And The General, the story of a Southern engineer and his train trying to do their duty during the Civil War, mixes pathos and slapstick in a stunning cinematic achievement.

Matan Porat, piano
Buster Keaton’s The General, with live improvised accompaniment


This concert is approximately one hour fifty minutes long. It is performed without intermission.

MobileDesc:
A performance installation, created by the Brentano Quartet, engineer Gabriel Calatrava and choreographer John-Mario Sevilla. The set design, operated by a corps of dancers, illuminates visually the themes and counterpoints of Bach’s masterpiece, performed live by the famed Brentano String Quartet.

Bach’s The Art of the Fugue, written near the end of his life, represents one of the great achievements of Western music. Not merely of academic interest, this is music of great purity and expressive gesture, deeply moving and fascinating. It is a work for which composers and artists throughout the ages have had the highest regard and which many have found to be a great inspiration.

Using instruments ranging from the quartet’s old Italian violins to Calatrava’s 3D printer, this performance installation aims to bring a new approach to one of the greatest musical creations of all time.

“Exhilarating ... this intensely physical quartet is defined by passion.”—The New York Times

“Like his celebrated father, Santiago … Gabriel has one foot in engineering and the other in architecture.”—New York magazine

MobileDesc:
“The muscular grace of Ohlsson’s playing spoke volumes … I found myself mesmerized.”—The Guardian

Viewing paintings in a museum or gallery is usually a silent affair, but two composers from opposite ends of Europe—Spain and Russia—wrote powerful musical works of art inspired by paintings they had seen. Performing them will be the equally powerful and world-renowned piano virtuoso, Garrick Ohlsson.

From Spain comes Granados’ Goyescas, inspired by Goya, who straddled the line between the Old Masters and the new moderns. From Russia comes Mussorgsky’s great Pictures at an Exhibition, an orchestral showpiece that will be heard in its original solo piano arrangement. The “Exhibition” was a selection of paintings by Viktor Hartmann (now remembered chiefly through this work). Only five have survived, and images of these paintings, along with works of Goya, will be on display at the concert. You’ll both see and hear inspiration at work.

Join us for a free pre-concert talk at 2 pm with your ticket, about Goya’s and Hartmann’s art, and their relationship to music.

Garrick Ohlsson, piano

GRANADOS: Goyescas, Op. 11
MUSSORGSKY: Pictures at an Exhibition

This concert is approximately one hour forty minutes long.
ShortDesc: “The muscular grace of Ohlsson’s playing spoke volumes … I found myself mesmerized.”—The Guardian
Title: Composers Inspired by Art with pianist Garrick Ohlsson

“Julian Rachlin is the real thing … a virtuoso with heart and a champion’s bearing.”—Los Angeles Times

“Ross's work begins with a realistic meditation … and progresses to a visual carnival.” – M (InTheArtWorld.com)

Beethoven’s music is audaciously rich in sonic colors. Now those colors come to life in a stunning 21st-century interpretation by video artist Clifford Ross and violinist Julian Rachlin. Ross takes vivid visual elements from his celebrated abstract video Harmonium Mountain—the elements are themselves snippets of his photographs of Colorado mountains—and reenvisions them through the musical lens of Beethoven’s violin sonatas. With the video imagery screening onstage, Rachlin, who gave 92Y a triumphant Brahms series in Nov 2012, will perform the iconic cycle.

Julian Rachlin, violin

“We still sat riveted at Daniil Trifonov, the 23-year-old Russian capable of making the hardiest critic go weak at the knees.”—The Times (London)

92Y offers a feast of Rachmaninoff—his early chamber music performed by musicians from the New York Philharmonic and the young Russian dynamo, Daniil Trifonov. In 2011, at only 20 years of age, he won both the Tchaikovsky and Rubinstein competitions.

As a young man, Rachmaninoff’s compositional idol was Tchaikovsky, and his two attempts at the string quartet—both unfortunately left unfinished—reflect his devotion to the master. His more famous Piano Trio was written to honor Tchaikovsky’s death and features his trademark Romantic melodies and virtuosity.

Daniil Trifonov, piano

Would you make your swan song a string quartet? The Pacifica Quartet, now beginning its third decade, presents the final quartets of three composers spanning 200 years 

Beethoven inherited the string quartet from Haydn and Mozart and transformed it exponentially into something incredibly profound; in his last quartet he challenges Fate itself. Jan√°ƒçek’s last quartet in contrast is a “manifesto of love for a married woman half his age, to whom he wrote more than 700 passionate letters.

The Pacifica Quartet is renowned for its exuberant performances and bold repertory choices. As fans of Elliott Carter, they’ve recorded all five Carter quartets. His fifth and final quartet shows how far the string quartet form has travelled—it’s in twelve movements, compared to Beethoven’s four.

Pinchas Zukerman is a master of our time; he’s set standards on every endeavor he’s undertaken: violinist, violist, conductor, artistic director, pedagogue and chamber musician. Now he brings his celebrated Trio to 92Y, performing two favorite chamber works worthy of their nicknames. The St. Lawrence String Quartet’s members “are fearless musicians whose spontaneity stretches past conventional interpretation and probes the music’s imaginative limits.”—The Washington Post

The St. Lawrence String Quartet brings its vivid energy to a program from the 18th to 21st centuries. Jan√°ƒçek’s String Quartet No. 1, was inspired not by the Beethoven Violin Sonata, but by Leo Tolstoy’s scandalous novella, The Kreutzer Sonata. From California comes a world premiere by composer Jonathan Berger.

But it’s Haydn who’s the main attraction of the evening. The String Quartet, Op. 71, No. 2, is one of six the “Apponyi” Quartets, dedicated to a count simply because he paid for the privilege. The pinnacle of Hadyn’s career may be his “London” symphonies, which were transformed into chamber music by the impresario who brought Haydn to London.

Ever wish you could be transported back in time to the innovation, spirit and glamour of the Jazz Age? Our opening night concert will be as close as it gets! The party starts with Gershwin’s masterworks, “Rhapsody in Blue” and the Piano Concerto in F, like you’ve never heard them before—in Ferde Grof√©’s original Jazz Band arrangements for the legendary Paul Whiteman and his Orchestra.

Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks, the Grammy winners renowned for their quintessentially authentic 1920s jazz band sound, join 2010 Gilmore Artist Kirill Gerstein, who is hailed for being equally virtuoso at classical and jazz piano. Maestro Maurice Peress—one time right-hand man to Leonard Bernstein and Duke Ellington—conducts. Together, they’ll bring to life the sound and sensibility of what these pieces were all about, capturing the uniquely authentic energy and optimism of their time.

Awarded the Royal Northern College of Music’s Gold Medal in 2011, Julian Clef was born in the state of Kerala, India, and had no formal piano education until he was 16 years old. He has given recitals throughout India and the UK, including Buckingham Palace and has appeared at the Prague International Festival, Chetham’s International Festival for Pianists and the Beethoven-Haus Bonn. In January 2015 he gave a successful debut performance with the Philharmonia Orchestra at Royal Festival Hall.

MobileDesc:
“Mr. Wosner’s singing tone and expressive musicality complemented Ms. Koh’s insightful, richly hued playing.”—The New York Times

Jennifer Koh and Shai Wosner share a mission to explore the continuum of classical music; they create links between composers of the past and present. And now they turn to Beethoven.

Over four programs at 92Y this season, they perform the complete Beethoven violin sonatas and each concert features a new work, co-commissioned by Ms. Koh and written by one of today’s finest composers, that has been inspired by one of the sonatas on the program.

In this first concert, they present a new work by jazz pianist/composer Vijay Iyer who builds bridges between classical music and jazz in his works. Mr. Iyer is the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s 2015/16 Artist in Residence and a 2013 MacArthur “Genius” Award recipient. When Koh and Wosner premiered his Bridgewater Fantasy this past April, it was hailed as “adventurous, yet accessible” (Santa Barbara Independent). 

Jennifer Koh, violin
Shai Wosner, piano

“The collaboration was nothing sort of brilliant.”—Santa Barbara Independent

Jennifer Koh and Shai Wosner have each created intriguing programs that draw lines between the canons of the classical music repertoire and exciting new works from our time. Now they double up to present a series of concerts on the true Olympian—Ludwig van Beethoven.

In each program Koh and Wosner perform select Beethoven violin sonatas interspersed with a new work co-commissioned by Ms. Koh. For this program the composer is the German J√∂rg Widmann, whose “Summer Sonata” is in response to Beethoven’s “Spring” Sonata. (Both should ease the pain of winter’s arrival.) Also a renowned clarinetist, Widmann is known for his playful and rebellious takes on the classical tradition. He came to 92Y in April 2013 for a series of concerts that juxtaposed his music with Mozart and others.

Jennifer Koh, violin
Shai Wosner, piano

Jennifer Koh and Shai Wosner—two artists popular with 92Y audiences for their engaging personas, innovative programming and thrilling performances—now join forces to explore the enormous impact Beethoven still wields over today’s composers and musicians.

In each program Koh and Wosner reveal the links between past and present by juxtaposing Beethoven violin sonatas with a new work, co-commissioned by Ms. Koh for Bridge to Beethoven, by one of today’s top composers, who takes his starting point from a sonata on his program. For this program the composer is San Francisco native Anthony Cheung: co-founder, artistic director and pianist of the Talea Ensemble in New York; and Young Composer Fellow at the Cleveland Orchestra.

MobileDesc:
“An exceptionally refined young ensemble with a translucent sound."—The New Yorker

Turbulent times often create great art. The dynamic young Daedalus Quartet presents extraordinary music from the Czech region over the last 80 years. The Quartet—in residence at Columbia University—is joined by members of SPEAKmusic, a collective of Columbia and Juilliard musicians and composers.

This program presents music by Czech composers who suffered under Nazis or Communist regimes—or both—and yet wrote often-exuberant music filled with the creative spirit. One work was written in a concentration camp, others written in exile, and some were lucky to have survived; they all deserve to be heard often. And honoring that legacy, a young Fullbright Scholar at Columbia has written music inspired by a Czech writer who mocked the Communist system.

Bonus: Buttenwieser Hall puts you in close proximity to the musicians, both physically and emotionally, so in this concert you can both see and hear the theremin, a techno-musical marvel. It is played by waving a hand through an electro-magnetic field, creating a sound instantly recognizable from mid-century horror and sci fi movies.

Daedalus Quartet

With pianist Deborah Bradley-Kramer and other members of SPEAKmusic

MobileDesc:
“A fascinating, even thrilling piano recital”—MusicWeb International

Ever get a tune stuck in your head? Meet a tune that has been stuck in composers’ heads for 300 years! A rising star of the new generation of pianist-composers, Matan Porat—Tel Aviv-born and Berlin-based—performs the program of his latest CD, Variations on a Theme by Scarlatti, which the Frankfurter Algemine Zeituing called “a fantastic album that one shoud hear over and over again.”

Porat begins with the theme from Scarlatti's Sonata in D minor K32, written in 1739. He then performs a steady stream of 24 pieces by composers ranging from Bach to Boulez by way of Chopin and Debussy—all using the same Scarlatti motif. It is a “theme and variations” that covers the entire history of piano composition – all in less than an hour. This is a program that demands immediacy and intimacy—hallmarks of the concert experience in Buttenwieser Hall.

Matan Porat, piano

MobileDesc:
“One of the finest young groups to emerge in our current golden age of string quartets.”—The New Yorker

Jewish folk music has been a cornerstone of a culture. Its rich melodies have inspired generations of composers. The “strikingly unique” (Cleveland Plain Dealer) Daedalus Quartet—quartet in residence at Columbia University—celebrates the music of one generation: Russian-Jewish composers of the early 1900s. Through the Society for Jewish Folk Music, these daring artists, schooled in Russian classical music, melded tradition and modernity to give Russian Jewish folk music a more contemporary sheen.

The Quartet celebrates both tradition and continuity by performing music of Society members Achron, Krein and Weinberg, and young composers of today who have found their own inspiration in this rich and lasting legacy, including 19-year-old Chason Goldfinger. Joining the Daedalus Quartet are members of SPEAKmusic, a collective of Columbia and Juilliard musicians and composers.

MobileDesc:
“Years ago when I first met Uakti, I saw their music and performance as a unique and beautiful contribution to the world of new and experimental music ... This CD represents a true melding of my music with their sensibilities. For me, it is a delight and a pleasure to hear the final result.” – Philip Glass

92Y helps World Music Institute close their 30th Anniversary Season with an incredible collaboration—American legend Philip Glass performs with Uakti, the otherworldly Brazilian ensemble who use only one-of-a-kind instruments that they build themselves (such as glass marimbas). Glass and Uakti first became acquainted when introduced by Paul Simon during the recording of his 1988 album Rhythm of the Saints, and have maintained a longstanding collaboration since—though one very rarely seen in performance. Glass has twice selected Uakti to perform his commissioned works, and he released five of their albums on his Point Music label. Among them was their critically-acclaimed 2006 recording of his music, Aguas Da Amazonia. Originally composed by Phillip Glass as a ballet commissioned by Grupo Corpo, Glass asked Uakti to perform the work. Uakti's principal composer Marco Ant√¥nio Guimar√£es arranged Aguas Da Amazonia for the group's custom built instruments—the first time Glass’s music was arranged by another composer. For this truly special concert Uakti and Philip Glass come together to recreate Aguas Da Amazonia for the first time ever in live performance.
ShortDesc: 92Y helps World Music Institute close their 30th Anniversary Season with an incredible collaboration—American legend Philip Glass performs with Uakti, the otherworldly Brazilian ensemble who use only one-of-a-kind instruments that they build themselves (such as glass marimbas).
Title: Uakti Performs Aguas Da Amazonia with Special Guest Philip Glass

MobileDesc:
“L. Subramaniam is the best this listener has heard…” – The New York Times

Immerse yourself in the music of India with an extraordinary performance by the revered Indian violinist L. Subramaniam; Sir Yehudi Menuhin wrote, “each time I listen to him, I am carried away in wonderment.”

His music is an explosion of color and sound, grounded in Hindu worship and steeped in the Carnatic musical tradition of Southern India that reaches back more than 3,000 years but has made the western violin its own. A Grammy-nominated artist, Mr. Subramaniam has made more than 200 recordings and has performed with such artists as Stevie Wonder, Herbie Hancock, Al Jarreau and Maynard Ferguson.

This performance is his first in New York since 2006 and is the only North American event in the Lakshminarayana Global Music Festival, which he founded and leads. He is joined by his son, violinist Ambi Subramaniam, and drummer Mahesh Krishnamurthy.
ShortDesc: “L. Subramaniam is the best this listener has heard…” – The New York Times
Title: L. Subramaniam: Indian Classical Violin

MobileDesc: Cuban trumpeter Arturo Sandoval became a prot√©g√© of the legendary jazz master Dizzy Gillespie shortly after the two first met in Havana in 1977, when the American jazzman came to Cuba to play a concert. It was the start of a friendship and creative inspiration that lasted 16 years. Now one of the world’s foremost jazz trumpeters, Arturo Sandoval is the winner of 10 Grammys, 6 Billboard Awards and is the 2013 recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

The brilliant Brazilian jazz singer/songwriter Luciana Souza brings a new supergroup and new songs to 92Y this November. Celebrating the transcendence of the language of music that is beyond words and genres, most of the ensemble’s music is wordless, except for its use of two poems by the great Leonard Cohen.

Souza is joined for this project by Benin-native and guitarist extraordinaire Lionel Loueke, Swiss-born harmonica virtuoso Gr√©goire Maret, bassist Massimo Biolcati, of Swedish and Italian descent, and Texan drummer Kendrick Scott, finding common ground in rhythm and the joy of music without boundaries. Their new album, Speaking in Tongues, comes out this September.

Luciana Souza, vocals
Lionel Loueke, guitar
Gr√©goire Maret, harmonica
Massimo Biolcati, bass
Kendrick Scott, drums
ShortDesc: “If Luciana did nothing more than sing, she’d still be a miracle.”—The Wall Street Journal
Title: Luciana Souza ‚ÄúSpeaking in Tongues‚Äù

MobileDesc:
“Staples' voice is a rich, liquid wonder...”—Rolling Stone

“[Osborne's] sweet yet husky voice is a wonderfully expressive instrument, bringing emotional honesty, a.k.a. soul, to every performance...”—American Songwriter

Grammy Award-winning legend Mavis Staples and multi-platinum recording artist Joan Osborne bring their highly anticipated Solid Soul tour to 92Y for one night only.

From her early days with the iconic Staple Singers, when she was on top of the charts with songs like the 1972 #1 hit “I’ll Take You There,” to her recent albums with Wilco’s Jeff Tweedy, Mavis Staples has been a leader in American music for six decades. The Solid Soul tour marks her first tour collaboration with Joan Osborne, the widely celebrated singer-songwriter who dominated Top 40 radio with her hit song “One of Us” and whose albums have garnered seven Grammy nominations.

Joan Osborne opens the show with her greatest hits and emotionally evocative songs. Mavis Staples then takes the stage for a set of her inimitable R&B and gospel, including hits from her 2013 album One True Vine. The two then join forces for an unforgettable finale.
ShortDesc: Grammy Award-winning legend Mavis Staples and multi-platinum recording artist Joan Osborne bring their highly anticipated Solid Soul tour to 92Y for one night only.
Title: Mavis Staples & Joan Osborne: Solid Soul

MobileDesc: A celebration of Jewish identity, heritage, interests and memories, actors portraying prominent personalities including Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Fran Drescher, Andy Cohen, Tony Kushner, Leonard Nimoy, Joan Rivers, Gwyneth Paltrow and Aaron Sorkin among others, reveal intimate thoughts and experiences about being Jewish, from experiences of anti-Semitism to others of pure joy. Featuring original songs by some of Broadway’s top composers and lyricists including Marvin Halmisch, David Shire and Nathan Tyson, this is a holiday concert not to be missed.

MobileDesc: Chair of Vocal Department, Voice, Chorus and Glee! Originally from Menomonie, Wisconsin Ann Hoyt has been living in NYC since 1994. She received her Masters in Music from Manhattan School of Music and her Bachelors in Music from Illinois Wesleyan University. Her voice teachers have included Dr. David Nott, Adele Addison, Barrington Coleman and Helen Hodam. Equally at home on the operatic or musical theater stage, Ann is also an accomplished recital artist and has collaborated with Rebel Baroque Orchestra, Union Avenue Opera in St. Louis and Trinity Church Wall Street. Ms. Hoyt can be heard as a soloist on H√§nssler and Naxos recording labels. Most recently she was the featured soprano soloist on Naxos’ The Complete Haydn Masses. Ann is the director of both the 92Y Junior Chorus and Glee Club. She has been on the faculty of the 92Y for over 10 years and her student's range in age from 8 to over 75 years!
ShortDesc: Chair of Vocal Department, Voice, Chorus and Glee! Originally from Menomonie, Wisconsin Ann Hoyt has been living in NYC since 1994.
Title: Faculty Concert: Ann Hoyt, voice

MobileDesc:
Aminda Asher holds a B.M. in cello performance from Indiana University’s Jacobs School of Music and a M.M. in Orchestral Performance from the Manhattan School of Music. Ms. Asher has appeared in concerts at many of New York’s greatest performance venues including Carnegie Hall’s Weill Recital Hall and Zankel Hall, The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s Rose Studio, Merkin Hall, Symphony Space, Bargemusic, and (Le) Poisson Rouge. She has performed with several regional orchestras in the New York metropolitan area including the Hudson Valley Philharmonic, Riverside Symphonia, The Chelsea Symphony and Astoria Symphony, and has also played for several musical theater productions with the Prospect Theater Company and Making Books Sing.

Outside of New York, Ms. Asher has performed with the New World Symphony in Miami, Fl, and the Santo Domingo Music Festival Orchestra in the Dominican Republic, as well as participating in the intensive summer study programs at the Music Academy of the West and the Banff Centre of the Arts Chamber Music Residency Program. An avid chamber musician, she regularly plays with a variety of chamber ensembles including neoLIT; a chamber group dedicated to performing contemporary music with a special emphasis on the programming of works by women composers.

Ms. Asher has held several teaching positions in the New York area, including the Summer Music Camp at the Manhattan School of Music, and is currently on the teaching faculties of the Herald Music School in Flushing, NY, and the Newark School of the Arts.

 

Described as “elegant” by The New York Times, pianist Arielle Levioff has appeared as a soloist in some of New York City’s most prestigious venues including Stern Auditorium and Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, Merkin Hall and Alice Tully Hall. She has also performed in Philadelphia, Washington D.C., throughout the Southeastern United States and internationally in London, France and Italy. Her concerto engagements include the Rapides Symphony (LA), the Lower Merion Symphony (PA), the Astoria Symphony (NY), the Christ Church Festival Orchestra in Oyster Bay (NY) and the Seniors Orchestral Society of New York. Ms. Levioff was a finalist in the 2009 Sorel Medallion Competition in Collaborative Piano, resulting in an invitation to join the faculty of the 2010 Daniel Ferro Vocal Festival in Tuscany.

Ms. Levioff earned her Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees from the Manhattan School of Music and attended prestigious summer festivals including the Tanglewood Institute and the American Conservatory in Fontainebleau, France. She has served on the piano and chamber music faculty of the 92nd Street Y School of Music since 2005, and also teaches piano and The Art of Listening to Music for the Himan Brown senior program at 92nd Street Y. An avid chamber musician, Ms. Levioff has enjoyed collaborations with the Ridotto Ensemble, The Phoenix Ensemble, The Westerlund Trio and musicians from the Orchestra of St. Luke’s. She is also Music Director of the Point Counterpoint Adult Chamber Music Workshop in Brandon, Vermont.
ShortDesc: Aminda Asher holds a B.M. in cello performance from Indiana University’s Jacobs School of Music and a M.M. in Orchestral Performance from the Manhattan School of Music. A native of Philadelphia, pianist Arielle Levioff is a versatile soloist and collaborative artist.
Title: Faculty Concert: Aminda Asher and Arielle Levioff

MobileDesc:
New York based-, Colombian born Hector Martignon has composed, orchestrated, produced, performed and recorded music in a wide spectrum of genres, from classical and crossover, to jazz and world music, to rock and pop. His five albums as a leader and two as co-leader (Mozart's Blue Fantasies and Bach's Secret Files) as well as his work on over a hundred albums, scores for five feature films, three Broadway Musicals and multiple other projects, showcase his wide-ranging area of expertise.


After several nominations as a sideman, two of his five solo CDs (Refugee, 2008, and Second Chance, 2010) were nominated for a GRAMMY Award. He arranged and performed parts of the score of Ang Lee's OSCAR-nominated movie Eat, Drink, Man, Woman.

His first professional recording was at age 18 (Mikis Theodorakis's Canto General) while one of the most recent was on legendary rock band Chicago's latest production, the Latin-tinged Exitos.

He has written symphonic orchestrations, performed and recorded by the Russian Philharmonic Orchestra and compositions like the one commissioned and premiered by the Musica de Camara String Orchestra at St. Patrick's Cathedral in April 2011.

As a requested sideman he has toured the world with such greats as Paquito D'Rivera, Ray Barretto, Gato Barbieri, Steve Turre, Don Byron, Tito Puente and, closer to home, he was featured pianist with Max Roach's "Project America" at the 92 St Y.

His joy of teaching has made him a requested guest-lecturer and performance teacher in music faculties and academies in several countries of Europe, North- and South America. Hector wrote an instructional book on Latin piano commissioned and published by Hal Leonard.
ShortDesc: New York based-, Colombian born Hector Martignon has composed, orchestrated, produced, performed and recorded music in a wide spectrum of genres, from classical and crossover, to jazz and world music, to rock and pop.
Title: Faculty Concert: Hector Martignon

MobileDesc:
New York based guitarist Nelson Riveros recently released his debut recording titled Camino Al Barrio, a Contemporary Latin-Jazz CD with a diverse array of rhythms and fresh improvisations. Camino al Barrio peaked at #8 on the Jazz Week World Music Chart. He was nominated among his peers as ‘Next Best Generation Artist’ and ‘Best Latin Jazz Guitar’ for the 2010 Latin Jazz Corner Best of The Year Awards.

Born of Colombian parents, Nelson grew up listening to his parent’s record collection, which was a staple that instilled him with a musical appreciation at an early age. Nelson began playing guitar in high school and became well versed in the styles of rock, jazz and latin. He studied with a very in demand guitar teacher named George Bien who turned him on to recordings by Joe Pass, Pat Martino, Wes Montgomery, Larry Carlton, Lee Ritenour and George Benson.

A graduate of City College where he received a B.F.A in Jazz Studies, Nelson studied guitar with Gene Bertoncini, Pete McCann and composition with Mike Holober. He also studied at Mannes College of Music with guitarist Vic Juris. Nelson has performed and recorded with Grammy nominated pianist Hector Martignon, Grammy winning bassist John Benitez, Samuel Torres, Luis Bonilla, Alfredo De La Fe and Adela Dalto. Nelson performed at the Jazz on the Vine Jazz Festival in Riverhead L.I., Miles Caf√©, Blue Water Grill, FB Lounge and Nuyorican Poets Caf√©.

Nelson is an active teacher and has been on the faculty of 92Y School of Music since 2005 as a teaching artist for 92Y’s Outreach Program.
ShortDesc: New York based guitarist Nelson Riveros recently released his debut recording titled Camino Al Barrio, a Contemporary Latin-Jazz CD with a diverse array of rhythms and fresh improvisations.
Title: Faculty Concert: Nelson Riveros, guitar

Merce Cunningham’s Fabrications (1987) was a full company dance with music by Emanuel Dimas de Melo Pimenta, and d√©cor by Dove Bradshaw. According to Cunningham, the title refers to both meanings of the verb “to fabricate”:  to combine parts to form a whole, and to invent or concoct, even to lie. Fabrications will be performed by young professional dancers from the Merce Cunningham Trust Fellowship Program. Alastair Macaulay, chief dance critic of The New York Times and Patricia Lent, MCT Director of Licensing, will be joined by a panel of dancers from the original cast of Fabrications to discuss the making and performing of the dance.
